dek: Senegal’s legendary Orchestra Baobab return with their first record in a decade—a tribute to the group’s longtime member Ndiouga Dieng, who passed away late last year.

title: Emperor of Sand
dek: Full of melodic singing and zig-zagging riffs, the new Mastodon LP reins-in the Atlanta metal band’s technical abilities without watering them down—though it smooths out some of their angular edges.

title: Let the Dancers Inherit the Party

promoTitle: Let the Dancers Inherit the Party
dek: British Sea Power evoke an eternal 1984, when bands bridged caustic post-punk and stadium-sized pop. Dismayed by the black cloud of post-Brexit Britain, they designed this album as a beacon of light.

title: Rather You Than Me
dek: The ninth Rick Ross album features tons of guests including Young Thug, Future, and Nas. As the Bawse enters his 40s, his bite has weakened, but he still owns his lane in luxury rap.

title: Mental Illness
dek: Mental Illness is Aimee Mann’s quintessential statement, tempering the discord of life with elegant chamber folk. Mann fills her songs with ordinary people struggling against operatic levels of pain.

title: Brood X
dek: Jon Spencer and his New York blues-punks return with their first new album in nearly two decades—a powerful showcase for singer Cristina Martinez and the fiery, apocalyptic buzz in her wake.

title: Instrumentals
dek: Newly remastered and reissued, Instrumentals is an ideal entry point into Russell’s pre-disco, magpie aesthetic. His early ideas as a downtown composer and cellist were both complex and joyful.
